Award.AwardTitle: Reduced Order Models of the Navier-Stokes Equations of Fluid Flows

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Turbulence is the apparently random motion that occurs commonly in almost all fluid flows. It has been called one of the most challenging unsolved problems in Newtonian physics. The aggregate cost to our society resulting from our incomplete understanding of turbulence is significant. Consider, for example, the environmental and economic costs associated with sub-optimal performance of virtually every fluid-thermal system such as internal combustion engines and air-conditioners. It is usually not possible to directly and routinely simulate turbulent flow because its multi-scale characteristics require prohibitively high computational resources. Even when adequate computational resources are available, simulations often provide too little understanding of the solutions they produce. There are significant scientific and engineering benefits in developing and studying (reduced-order) models of turbulence that retain the needed physical fidelity while substantially reducing the size and cost of the computational model. The ultimate goal of reduced-order modeling of turbulence is to provide efficient and accurate solutions with minimal reliance on auxiliary empirical models. Empirical models are inherently undesirable because they degrade simulation accuracy and reliability.

The research objective of this project is to develop a reduced-order modeling approach to turbulent fluid flows that is free of empirical closure models. Unlike traditional approaches, the new methodology does not rely on empirical turbulence modeling or ad hoc modification of the Navier-Stokes equations. It provides spatial basis functions different from the usual proper orthogonal decomposition basis function in that, in addition to optimally representing the solution, the new basis functions also provide stable reduced-order models. The approach is illustrated with three test cases: two-dimensional flow inside a square lid-driven cavity, two-dimensional mixing layer, and three-dimensional turbulent flow around the Ahmed body. Future work will extend this method to more complex flows including the effects of higher spatial dimensions and higher flow velocities (Reynolds numbers).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Turbulence is the nonlinear dynamic phenomenon that occurs in fluid flows and is characterized by random and chaotic oscillations. It is ubiquitous in fluid flows from the nanoscale to the macroscale. Ground, sea and air ransportation vehicles; flow of chemicals and fuels; energy sources of many types that rely on turbines to convert fluid mechanical energy to electrical energy are among the key technoligies that depend on devices that must take into account turbulent flows. Current mathematical models of turbulence rely on some degree of empiricism of unknown accuracy. It is widely believed that if one could obtain a solution of the three dimensional time dependent Navier-Stokes equations that this would provide a rational and accurate model of turbulence.

 

In this work several novel approaches have been created to develop such solutions. This involves finding a way to reduce the very high dimensionality fo the standard mathematical models which may involve millions of degrees of freedom and more and the corresponding number of equations that must be solved. One approach involves finding characteristic modes of the fluid flow using a variety of techniques that retain the essence of the physical phenomena of turbulence while requiring only a relatively small number of modes, say less than one hundred. Another approach is to filter the Navier-Stokes equations so that only a certain range of frequencies and wavelengths in the fluid flow are retained.

 

Several publications describe our success with these approaches. Initial results are promising, but it is too soon to declare victory.
